titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Carole De Saram Collection of Posters
1970-2002
PR 371
titlestmt.author: Zora Arum and Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:47:22 -0400.

did.unittitle: Carole De Saram collection of posters
did.abstract: This collection consists of posters from the 1970s-early 2000s, including promotional posters for events around New York City (particularly in Tribeca), posters concerning the women's movement of the 1970s, maps, movie and television advertisements, prints of artwork from earlier time periods, and calendars.
did.langmaterial: The bulk of the documents in the collection are in English; one is in Spanish.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The posters are arranged with posters related to New York City (mainly Tribeca) first, followed by reproductions of artwork and advertisements for art shows, then movie and television posters, then assorted miscellaneous posters and calendars. Posters related to the women's movement, which were donated after the bulk of the collection was processed, are found at the end of the container list, together in one folder.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carole De Saram was a community organizer and activist in the 1970s and 1980s. A longtime Tribeca resident, she served as both the Chair of Manhattan Community Board 1 and the President of the Tribeca Community Association. She worked diligently to improve living conditions in Tribeca and to keep the community safe and engaged, as well as to get Tribeca landmarked as a historic district. De Saram was also an avid feminist, and served as President of the National Organization for Women's New York City Chapter.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The bulk of the collection was donated by Carole De Saram in May and July 2018. An additional thirteen posters (noted in the container list) were donated in 2020-21.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as the Carole De Saram collection of posters, PR 371, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit line: Donated by Carole De Saram.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by archival intern Zora Arum in 2018, with additional posters included in 2020-21 by archivist Larry Weimer.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The New-York Historical Society also owns the Carole De Saram papers, which were donated by De Saram in 2016 and contain records of her work as a community organizer in Tribeca.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of over 50 posters from the 1970s-early 2000s collected by Carole De Saram. These are primarily related to events in New York City and Tribeca, as well as popular culture, including movies, art exhibitions, and political conferences. Several of the posters relate to the women's movement of the 1970s-1980s. Some of the posters are reproductions of earlier artwork, and there are also some wall calendars and maps.

did.unittitle: Hagstrom Map. "New York City: Manhattan House Numbers and Transit Guide" (Oversize)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by Richard Bernstein and sponsored by American Airlines. Fair held on 52nd street, from Broadway East to 3rd Avenue.

did.unittitle: Burger King New York Yankees Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster with printed drawings by Frank Becerra of the team members.

did.unittitle: "Community Board #1: Borough of Manhattan Presents 'Use of Toxins in an Urban Environment'" Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Promotional poster for event, with artwork by Mario Pikus on the dangers of fumigating with methyl bromide.

did.unittitle: Tribeca Benefit Art Auction Poster (2 copies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Features drawing of eagle by Mimi Gross.

did.unittitle: The Texture of Tribeca Promotional Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster to promote Andrew Scott Dolkart's illustrated history of Tribeca, The Texture of Tribeca.

did.unittitle: Uprooting Poverty Through Community Development Conference Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In honor of the 25th anniversary of the Pratt Center for Environmental Development. Artwork by Lorenz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Promotional poster for parade honoring Persian Gulf War veterans. Artwork by Milton Glaser.

did.unittitle: "Celebrating Historic Preservation: Civic Fame: Municipal Building, City of New York""

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Municipal buiding statue renovation. Published by Mayor David Dinkins's office during his mayoral tenure. Photograph by Gaston Dubois.

did.unittitle: "An Axonometric View of the 'Triangle Below Canal'"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Aerial map of Tribeca by Ludington Ltd..

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Very colorful promotional poster, designed by Peter Max.

did.unittitle: "Listening to the City" Town Hall Event at Jacob Javits Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 identical posters from "Listening to the City" event held at Jacob Javits Center, July 20, 2002. Project of Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York. Includes various images depicting development of lower Manhattan from colonial period to the World Trade Center. Donated March 2020 and added to collection in October 2020.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of Tribeca map from before the Battery Park City landfill was completed in 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informational poster released by the New York State Temporary Commission on Dioxin Exposure. The poster has two business cards for Vietnam Veterans of America offices in New York City stapled to it.

did.unittitle: "New York Needs You--Join The Auxiliary Police"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by "Schlamp," for New York City Police Foundation.

did.unittitle: Layered Print of Swan and Heron

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Print by "J. Yelton" (?).

did.unittitle: New Deal Art Golden Anniversary Posters (5)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Posters feature prints of Lily Furedi's Subway, LaVerne Nelson Black's Jicarilla "Apache Fiesta", Jenne Magafan's The Windmill, O. Louis Guglielmi's Martyr Hill, and Ilya Bolotowsky's In The Barber Shop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By William Hogarth.

unittitle.emph: Tight Lacing, Or Fashion Before Ease

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Replica poster of the original satirical print by John Collet.

did.unittitle: Print of Painting Depicting Animals, Columns, and Pyramids

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Painting originally by English artist Julie Arkell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Distributed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes "Coit Tower, San Francisco," watercolors by Cecile Johnson and an image from "Batiks by Winifred Madison."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Of photographs from the original television show.

unittitle.emph: Star Wars: Return of the Jedi Poster

did.unittitle: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reads, "YOUR MISSION: BEGINS AT HTTP://WWW.MISSION.APPLE.COM/," with a picture of Tom Cruise.

did.unittitle: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Movie Poster
The Day After Tomorrow Movie Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Produced by Chinese Native Products and Pearl River Chinese Products Emporium, with Chinese art prints and advertisements for "Bee and Flower" soap on the pages inside.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With guide to Mexican religious imagery printed on the back.

did.unittitle: Presidents of the United States Poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Distributed by Bayside Fuel Oil Corp, with biographical information about each president printed on the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Promotional poster for Preservation Week, published by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reproduction of poster from 1903 New York State Fair in Syracuse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster with "Born Free" lyrics, written by Don Black and John Barry, and an African savannah landscape underneath.

did.unittitle: The New Game of Human Life (2 copies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reprints of the 1790 game.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 posters. The first is an original "Women Unite!" poster with artwork signed "Jeannie Friedman, Newark, 1970." This poster was used to glue on the words "National Organization for Women" across the top; the word "Organization" is missing now. From this the second poster, a reproduction, was made and used, according to the donor, at City National Bank for "Close Account Day" in 1971. (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster for march beginning on Fifth Avenue at 44th Street and going to rally at 72nd Street mall, New York City. Seeking "Our rights to: abortion, political power, child care centers, equality under the law, equal education and employment." With women's power logo. (Donated and added to the collection in March 2021.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issued by the U.S. Government Printing Office. Artwork by Howard Chandler Christy, 1917. (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

did.unittitle: "Infonavit â€“ Ano Internacional De La Mujer, Programa Cultural - Junio de 1975"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster text includes the program of events for June 21-30, 1975. In Spanish. (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster of poem "Good Carpenters" by Erica Jong, with small drawing. Presentation note on poster indicates it was done by Jong for Betty Friedan on the occasion of the publication of her book "It Changed My Life" and presented to Friedan by Carole de Saram, Muriel Fox, Elinor Guggenheimer, Elizabeth Forsling Harris, Eleanor Holmes Norton, Marlene Sanders, Ellen Sulzberger Straus, Mary Jean Tully. Paul Freeman, scribat. (Donated and added to the collection in March 2021.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artwork by J.B. Printed in Scotland. Minerva Denmark/Switzerland. (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster for conference held by the New York Chapter of the National Organization for Women, October 21-22, 1978, at Washington Irving High School in Manhattan. Poster text includes the program of speakers, panels, and topics. (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artwork is an embroidery from the Project by Pamella Nesbit. Text includes reference to "other creative visions by Judy Chicago." (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)

did.unittitle: "Women of the Forth World. NEW-Movement for a New Community. New-York. Paris. London"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With text echoing Sojourner Truth, ending in "Am I not a woman?" (Donated and added to the collection in November 2020)
